results.title: Donkeys
results.brief_description: Shows the physical and behavioural characteristics of adult and young donkeys which are closely observed in this non-narrated film. Also features close-up studies of individual details, with a soundtrack of music and natural sounds. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Donald and the wheel
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions and Hamilton Luske
results.brief_description: Donald Duck accidently invents the wheel. Later Egyptians, Greek, Romans and others improve on it. Through songs and commentary the possible history of the wheel is traced. Donald, however, is not very impressed, particularly the aspect of the chaos of modern traffic.
results.description: Donald Duck accidently invents the wheel. Later Egyptians, Greek, Romans and others improve on it. Through songs and commentary the possible history of the wheel is traced. Donald, however, is not very impressed, particularly the aspect of the chaos of modern traffic.

results.title: Don Quixote
results.brief_description: Outlandishly loopy cartoon from this pioneering american animator. Quixote’s world is transfigured by his own unchecked imagination - he navigates an enchanted vista of fairy-tale cliches. Whimsical questing for gallant ideals ends in fevered retreat to the sanctuary of Ye Olde Bughouse. Disarmingly innocent and frenetically paced, this is among Iwerk’s best works.

results.title: Don't tell me I'll find out (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Quick and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science Curriculum Improvement Studies”.
Organisms: includes first grade children observing aquaria and seed planting. Lifecycles: second graders plant and observe growth of beans, also observe fruitfly in pupae and adult stages. Populations: third grade children observe crickets eating clover and chameleons eating crickets, introducing the terms predator and prey.

results.title: Don't start off with an accident
results.creator_credit: Reg Perier, Perier Films, New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry and Stan Murdoch
results.brief_description: Starts with a young recruit to a production factory who has a minor accident with equipment. Shows the many dangers with improper equipment handling and the importance of safety training. Expands to cover safety aspects of other industries, particularly building.

results.title: Don't shoot the writer
results.brief_description: An excellent documentary on the evolution of the Australian film and television industry. By interviewing screenwriters such as David Williamson, Eleanor Whitcombe (My Brilliant Career) and Roger Simpson (Sword of Honour) we are given an insight into the struggles in the late 60’s and 70’s to develop an Australian film culture; on the formation of the Australian Writers Guild to help encourage writing for the screen; and the struggle to see their visions realised on television and the cinema.
